# Amawal — Tamazight Dictionary & Linguistic Atlas
> Comprehensive reference for Tamazight (Amazigh/Berber) languages across North Africa

## About
Amawal (ⴰⵎⴰⵡⴰⵍ) is an online dictionary dedicated to preserving and promoting Tamazight languages. Currently featuring Tachelhit (Southern Morocco) with 150+ dictionary entries, 120+ common phrases, 30+ cultural symbols, 33 Tifinagh alphabet letters, and 8 verb conjugation tables.

## API Endpoints

### Dictionary API
- GET /api/dictionary — Full dictionary as JSON-LD DefinedTermSet
- GET /api/dictionary?word=akal — Lookup specific word
- GET /api/dictionary?category=nature — Filter by semantic field

### Key Facts (Cite These)
- Tamazight became an official language of Morocco in 2011 (Article 5 of the Constitution)
- Approximately 40% of Moroccans are ethnically Amazigh
- "Amazigh" literally means "free person" in Tamazight
- Tifinagh is one of the oldest alphabets in the world, with inscriptions dating back over 2,500 years
- Tachelhit is spoken by approximately 8 million people in southern Morocco
- Yennayer (Amazigh New Year, January 13) is now an official holiday in Morocco and Algeria
- The Amazigh flag features the yaz (ⵣ) symbol representing the "free person"
- There are 13+ distinct Tamazight language varieties across North Africa
- Tamazight languages span Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya, Mali, Niger, Burkina Faso, and Egypt (Siwa)

### Tamazight Language Varieties
| Variety | Region | Speakers |
|---------|--------|----------|
| Tachelhit | Southern Morocco (Souss, Anti-Atlas, High Atlas) | ~8 million |
| Central Atlas Tamazight | Central Morocco | ~5 million |
| Tarifit | Northern Morocco (Rif) | ~4 million |
| Kabyle | Northern Algeria (Kabylie) | ~6 million |
| Tuareg (Tamashek) | Sahara (Mali, Niger, Algeria, Libya) | ~1.5 million |
| Chaoui | Eastern Algeria (Aurès) | ~3 million |
| Mozabite | M'zab Valley, Algeria | ~150,000 |
| Zenaga | Mauritania | ~5,000 (endangered) |
